questions.text: What effect does aldosterone have on acid secretion in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and collecting duct (CD)?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreases the activity of H ᐩ -ATPase.

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibits the secretion of H ᐩ .

options.label: C
options.text: Increases the activity of H ᐩ -ATPase

questions.correct_answer: C. Increases the activity of H ᐩ -ATPase

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a component of the juxtaglomerular (JG) apparatus?
questions.correct_answer: D. Loop of Henle

questions.text: Why is inulin clearance the gold standard for measuring glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Inulin is readily available and naturally produced in the body

options.label: B
options.text: Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of GFR.

options.label: C
options.text: Inulin has a high plasma concentration that enhances measurement accuracy

options.label: D
options.text: Inulin is rapidly metabolised by the kidneys, making it easier to measure

questions.correct_answer: B. Inulin is freely filtered and neither reabsorbed nor secreted, providing an accurate measurement of GFR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Glomerular Basement Membrane (GBM) is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not a part of the glomerular filtration barrier

options.label: D
options.text: Charges of substances do not affect their permeability through GBM

questions.correct_answer: C. Excludes substances larger than 8 nm
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Structure

A specialized membrane forming a sheath shared by neighboring capillaries

Contents
  • Fine fibrils in a gel-like matrix
  • The matrix contains type 4 collagen, laminin, fibronectin, and other negatively charged proteins

Permeability
  • Permits free passage of neutral substances up to 4 nm in diameter
  • Excludes substances larger than 8 nm

Molecular Charge Influence

Charge on molecules affects their passage into Bowman's capsule.

questions.text: Which part of the proximal tubule is the most vulnerable and prone to ischemia?
questions.correct_answer: C. S3
questions.explanation:
S1

S2

S3

Location

Proximal to the glomerulus.

Between S1 and S3.

Near the loop of Henle.

Function

Reabsorption of nutrients, ions, and water.

Reabsorption of water, ions, and bicarbonate.

Reabsorption of sodium, bicarbonate, and nutrients.

Features

High brush border density.

A brush border is present but less extensive than S1.

High mitochondrial density.

Risk of ischaemia

Least prone

Intermediate

Most prone

questions.text: Match each component of the countercurrent system with its respective function: Components Functions 1. Ascending Limb of Loop of Henle a. Blood loses water and gains solutes as it passes through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium. 2. Descending Limb of Loop of Henle b. Blood gains water and loses solutes as it passes through the less concentrated interstitium. 3. Ascending Vasa Recta c. Actively transports sodium and chloride into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate. 4. Descending Vasa Recta d. Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate.
questions.explanation:
Countercurrent Multiplier System

Countercurrent Exchanger System

Location: Loop of Henle

Location: Vasa Recta

Function: Creates an osmotic gradient in the renal medulla to concentrate urine

Function: Maintains the osmotic gradient established by the countercurrent multiplier system and supplies nutrients to the medulla

Descending Limb: Permeable to water; water is reabsorbed into the interstitium, concentrating the filtrate

Descending Vasa Recta: Blood loses water, and gains solute as it descends through the hyperosmotic medullary interstitium

Ascending Limb: Impermeable to water; actively transports sodium and chloride out into the interstitium, diluting the filtrate

Ascending Vasa Recta: Blood gains water and loses solutes as it ascends through the less concentrated interstitium.

Mechanism: Countercurrent flow between descending and ascending limbs multiplies the osmotic gradient, enabling the concentration of urine

Mechanism: Countercurrent exchange of water and solutes between blood in the vasa recta and the surrounding interstitium preserves the osmotic gradient

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between cortical and juxtamedullary nephrons?

options.label: A
options.text: Cortical nephrons have longer loops of Henle.

options.label: B
options.text: Juxtamedullary nephrons constitute approximately 85% in the kidney.

options.label: C
options.text: Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Juxtamedullary nephrons are located primarily in the renal cortex, whereas cortical nephrons are in the renal medulla.

questions.correct_answer: C. Cortical nephrons usually have a higher filtration rate.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Cortical Nephrons

Juxtamedullary Nephrons

Location

Renal cortex.

Near the boundary between the renal cortex and medulla.

Percentage of Total Nephrons

Approximately 85%

Approximately 15%

Loop of Henle

Short and extends only into the outer medulla.

Long and extends deep into the inner medulla.

Vasa Recta

Short and less extensive.

Long vasa recta, which follows the loop of Henle into the medulla.

Glomerular Capsule

Has a larger surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle.

Smaller surface area relative to the length of the loop of Henle.

Filtration Rate

High

Lower filtration rate but more specialised in concentration.

Presence of Macula Densa

Typically not present.

These nephrons are closely associated with the juxtaglomerular apparatus.

Function

Primarily involved in regulating blood composition and volume through reabsorption and secretion.
  • Concentration of urine due to the longer loops and extensive vasa recta
  • Contributing to the medullary osmotic gradient.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is responsible for maintaining the counter-current exchange mechanism in the kidney?
questions.correct_answer: C. Vasa Recta
questions.explanation:
Aspect of Vasa Recta

Details

Function

  • Maintains the osmotic gradient established by the loops of Henle, crucial for concentrated urine production.

Structure
  • Hairpin-loop blood vessels that descend and ascend alongside the loops of Henle.

Descending Limb
  • Solutes (NaCl and urea) diffuse from the interstitium into the vasa recta.
  • Water moves out of the vasa recta into the interstitium due to the osmotic gradient.
  • Result: Blood becomes more concentrated as it descends.

Ascending Limb
  • Solutes diffuse from the vasa recta into the interstitium.
  • Water moves from the interstitium into the vasa recta.
  • The ascending vasa recta are fenestrated to facilitate this exchange.

Net Effect
  • Role: Prevents dissipation of the osmotic gradient.
  • Outcome: Maintains the hypertonicity of the medulla, essential for water reabsorption and concentrated urine production.

Conclusion:
  • Works with the loops of Henle to establish and maintain medullary osmotic gradient

questions.text: Which of the following statements about urea transport in the kidneys is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: UT-A1 and UT-A3 in the cortical collecting duct are regulated by aldosterone

options.label: B
options.text: Urea helps establish the osmotic gradient in the medullary pyramids but is not involved in urine concentration.

options.label: C
options.text: A high-protein diet reduces the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine.

options.label: D
options.text: UT-B is found in erythrocytes and the descending limbs of the vasa recta.

questions.correct_answer: D. UT-B is found in erythrocytes and the descending limbs of the vasa recta.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Osmotic Gradient

Urea helps establish it in medullary pyramids

Concentrated Urine

Formed with the help of urea in collecting ducts

Urea Transporters
  • UT-A1 to UT-A4 in kidneys
  • UT-B in erythrocytes, and vasa recta

Key Collecting Duct Transporters

UT-A1, UT-A3, regulated by vasopressin

Vasopressin Role

Increases urea in medullary interstitium during antidiuresis

Dietary Impact

High-protein diet increases, low-protein diet decreases urine concentrating ability

questions.text: What is the primary aim of the counter-current mechanism in the kidneys?

options.label: A
options.text: To dilute urine for better excretion of waste products

options.label: B
options.text: To conserve sodium and chloride ions in the body

options.label: C
options.text: To concentrate urine and maintain fluid and electrolyte balance

options.label: D
options.text: To increase blood flow to the renal cortex

questions.correct_answer: C. To concentrate urine and maintain fluid and electrolyte balance

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prerequisite for a functional counter-current mechanism in the body?

options.label: A
options.text: Parallel and opposite flow of fluids

options.label: C
options.text: Active transport of solutes across all segments

questions.correct_answer: C. Active transport of solutes across all segments

questions.text: What triggers the formation of ammonium ions (NH4 ᐩ ) and bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) in the ammonia buffer system?
questions.correct_answer: C. Acidosis
questions.explanation:
BUFFERS

DESCRIPTION

Bicarbonate Buffer
  • Most powerful extracellular buffer system.
  • Composed of H2CO3 and NaHCO3
  • Buffers strong acids by forming H2CO3 and strong bases by reacting with H+ to form H2O and CO2.
  • Effective due to regulation by kidneys and lungs.

Phosphate Buffer
  • Composed of H2PO4⁻ and HPO4.
  • pK of 6.8, effective in slightly acidic urine.
  • Phosphate concentration increases in tubular fluid due to water reabsorption.

Ammonia Buffer
  • Composed of ammonia (NH3) and ammonium ion (NH4ᐩ).
  • In the liver, Glutamine metabolized to 2NH4ᐩ and 2HCO3−.
  • NH4ᐩ is secreted into the tubular lumen
  • HCO3− reabsorbed into blood.
  • Acidosis stimulates NH4ᐩ and HCO3⁻ formation; alkalosis decreases their formation.
  • The rate of NH4ᐩ excretion can increase significantly with chronic acidosis.

Others

(less significant)
  • Urate Buffer
  • Citrate Buffer

questions.text: While flowing through which of the following segments does the filtrate become progressively hypertonic compared to plasma?
questions.correct_answer: C. B
questions.explanation:
Nephron Segment

Tonicity relative to Plasma

Filtration (Glomerulus)

Isotonic (Same as plasma osmolality)

Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)

Isotonic

  • Absorption of solute is proportional to the reabsorption of water.

Thin Descending Limb

Hypertonic (Water reabsorption, no solute reabsorption)

  • Isotonic - - - - -> Hypertonic

Thick Ascending Limb

  • Hypertonic - - - - - > Isotonic
    • (Solute reabsorption, no water reabsorption)

Distal Convoluted Tubule (DCT)

Hypotonic

Collecting Duct (CD)

It depends upon the presence of ADH in the blood
  • With ADH, more reabsorption of water and Hypertonic.
  • Without ADH, water reabsorption is nil, which is more hypotonic.

questions.text: Which transport mechanism is primarily responsible for bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT)?
questions.correct_answer: B. Na ᐩ -H ᐩ antiporter

questions.text: How does the excretion of ammonium (NH4+) contribute to bicarbonate (HCO3⁻) regulation in the kidneys?

options.label: A
options.text: It directly increases the concentration of HCO3⁻ in the urine.

options.label: B
options.text: It generates HCO3⁻ , which is released into the bloodstream.

options.label: C
options.text: It decreases the overall HCO3⁻ reabsorption in the kidneys.

options.label: D
options.text: It prevents the secretion of H+ in the renal tubules.

questions.correct_answer: B. It generates HCO3⁻ , which is released into the bloodstream.
questions.explanation:
Mechanism

Description

Filtration and Reabsorption

Bicarbonate is filtered from the blood in the glomeruli. Approximately 85% to 90% is reabsorbed in the proximal tubule, with the remaining 10% reabsorbed in the distal tubule and collecting ducts.

Transport Mechanisms

Bicarbonate reabsorption across the basolateral membrane of renal tubular cells occurs via sodium-bicarbonate cotransporters. This process excretes one hydrogen ion for each bicarbonate ion reabsorbed.

Role of Ammonium

Ammonium (NH4+) excretion in the kidneys, derived from amino acid metabolism, generates bicarbonate ions released into the bloodstream, aiding in bicarbonate homeostasis.

questions.text: What is the approximate daily production of non-volatile (metabolic) acids in an adult human body?
questions.correct_answer: B. 70 to 100 mmol
questions.explanation:
Type of Acid

Production Range

Excretion Route

Nonvolatile (Metabolic/Fixed)

70 to 100 mmol H+ per day

40% via phosphate systems

60% via NH4+ excretion

Volatile (Respiratory)

12,000 to 24,000 mmol

Exhaled as carbon dioxide (CO2)

questions.text: When a nephrologist studying kidney reabsorption encounters the effects of Anti-diuretic hormone (ADH) on water reabsorption, what is the most likely influence of ADH on water reabsorption?

options.label: A
options.text: Facultative water reabsorption involves glucose transporters

options.label: D
options.text: Facultative reabsorption occurs in proximal tubules

questions.correct_answer: B. Facultative reabsorption dependent on ADH
questions.explanation:
Feature

Facultative Water Absorption

Obligatory Water Absorption

Location

Distal convoluted tubules and collecting ducts.

Proximal convoluted tubules and descending limb of the loop of Henle.

Mechanism

Insertion of aquaporin-2 channels via ADH

Follows solute (mainly sodium) reabsorption due to osmotic gradient.

Effect of ADH

Increases water reabsorption

Not influenced by ADH

Result

Concentrated urine when ADH is high.

Constant reabsorption rate.

questions.text: Which channels are not typically found on the luminal side of principal cells in the DCT?
questions.correct_answer: D. Na+-K+-2Cl- cotransporter (NKCC2)
questions.explanation:
Channel/Transporter

Location

Role

Epithelial Sodium Channel (ENaC)

  

Luminal membrane

Sodium reabsorption from the tubular lumen into the cell.

Renal Outer Medullary Potassium (ROMK) channel

Potassium secretion from the cell into the tubular lumen.

Aquaporin-2 (AQP2) water channel

Water reabsorption under the influence of ADH.

Aquaporin - Type 3/4

  

Basolateral membrane

Water reabsorption from cell cytoplasm to blood.

Na+-K+ ATPase pump

Active transport of sodium out of the cell into blood and potassium into the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic feature of Gitelman syndrome?
questions.correct_answer: C. Hypomagnesemia

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bartter's syndrome is NOT true?

options.label: A
options.text: Caused by mutations in the sodium-chloride-potassium co-transporter in the loop of Henle.

options.label: B
options.text: Common features include hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.

options.label: C
options.text: Typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

options.label: D
options.text: Leads to the activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

questions.correct_answer: C. Typically inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the roles of principal cells and type A intercalated cells in the distal convoluted tubule (DCT) and cortical collecting ducts?

options.label: A
options.text: Type B intercalated cells reabsorb bicarbonate ions and secrete hydrogen ions.

options.label: B
options.text: Type B intercalated cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions

options.label: C
options.text: Principal cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions into the tubular lumen.

options.label: D
options.text: Type A intercalated cells reabsorb potassium ions and secrete bicarbonate.

questions.correct_answer: C. Principal cells reabsorb sodium and secrete potassium ions into the tubular lumen.
questions.explanation:
Cell

Channel / Pump

Side

Function

Principal Cells

(Option C)

Na+-K+ ATPase pump

Basolateral membrane

Exchanges sodium with potassium in renal interstitial fluid.

Sodium channels

Luminal membrane

Reabsorb sodium from the lumen.

Potassium channels

Luminal membrane

Secrete potassium into the lumen..

Type A Intercalated Cells

(Option D)

H+-ATPase pump

Luminal membrane

Secrete hydrogen ions into the lumen.

H+-K+ ATPase pump

Luminal membrane

Reabsorb potassium ions from the lumen.

Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger

Basolateral membrane

Exchanges Chloride with bicarbonate into the interstitial fluid.

Type B Intercalated Cells

(Option A and B)

H+-ATPase pump

Basolateral membrane

Reabsorb hydrogen ions.

Chloride-bicarbonate exchanger (Pendrin)

Apical membrane

Secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding potassium homeostasis by the renal tubule is NOT True?

options.label: A
options.text: Maximum K+ reabsorption occurs in the PCT.

options.label: B
options.text: Principal cells are the major site for K+ secretion.

options.label: C
options.text: Reabsorption of K+ in the PCT depends on the daily changes in potassium intake.

options.label: D
options.text: Type B intercalated cells secrete potassium into the tubule when there is excess K+.

questions.correct_answer: C. Reabsorption of K+ in the PCT depends on the daily changes in potassium intake.
questions.explanation:
Site

Potassium reabsorption and secretion

PCT
  • Maximum potassium reabsorption (65%).
  • Does not depend on daily K+ intake.

Loop of Henle

  • About 30% of K+ is reabsorbed.
  • Potassium is cotransported with sodium and chloride.

DCT and Collecting duct

Principal cells
  • Major site for potassium secretion
  • Na+-K+ ATPase pump moves K+ into the cell from the interstitium.
  • Passive diffusion of K+ from the cell into the tubular lumen through ROMK and BK channels.

Type A intercalated cells.
  • Reabsorbs potassium during potassium depletion.
  • Mechanism: Hydrogen-potassium ATPase transporter in the luminal membrane exchanges hydrogen ions for potassium

Type B intercalated cells
  • Secrete potassium when there is an excess.
  • Mechanism: Hydrogen-potassium ATPase transporter on the basolateral membrane pumps potassium into the cell, which then diffuses into the tubular lumen.

questions.text: At which part of the renal tubule does the maximum reabsorption of sodium occur?
questions.correct_answer: A. Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.text: Where is the sodium-glucose-linked transporter (SGLT) located in the renal tubule?

options.label: A
options.text: Early part of the Proximal convoluted tubule

options.label: D
options.text: Later part of the Proximal convoluted tubule

questions.correct_answer: A. Early part of the Proximal convoluted tubule
questions.explanation:
PART of TUBULE

TRANSPORTERS

Proximal tubule






 

Early PCT (Option A)

  • Sodium-Glucose Co-transporter (SGLT)
  • Sodium-Amino Acid Cotransporter
  • Sodium-Hydrogen Exchanger (NHE)
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump

Late PCT (Option D)

  • Sodium-Chloride Cotransporter
  • Chloride Channels

Thin descending loop of Henle

  • Freely permeable to water and some solutes such as urea and sodium
  • No specific transporter

Thick ascending loop of Henle

(Option B)
  • Na+-K+-2Cl− Co-transporter (NKCC2)
  • Sodium-Hydrogen Exchanger
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump

Distal convoluted tubule (Option C)



 

 

Early DCT

  • Sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC)
  • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump
  • Chloride Channels

Late DCT

  • Principal Cells:
    • Epithelial Sodium Channels (ENaC)
    • Potassium Channels
    • Na+/K+ ATPase Pump
  • Type A Intercalated Cells:
    • Hydrogen-ATPase
    • Hydrogen-Potassium ATPase
    • Chloride-Bicarbonate Exchanger
  • Type B Intercalated Cells:
    • Hydrogen-ATPase (Basolateral)
    • Chloride-Bicarbonate Exchanger (Pendrin)
